paragraphs.title: The Opposite
paragraphs.p: The symbol "–" is commonly referred to as a “negative sign”, but it often helps to read it as “the opposite of”.

For instance, we can interpret the expression -3 as the opposite of 3, and we can interpret 13 as the opposite of -13. If a is any number, then -a is the opposite of a, regardless of whether a itself is actually positive or negative.
This is particularly useful when we don't know if a variable is positive or negative.
We refer to -x as the opposite of x, and we avoid saying "negative" x.

section.p: Check your understanding in the next exercise, where you will locate the opposite of a number.

section.p: For a function g(x), the transformation g(-x) does something else.
If you wanted to evaluate g(-x) when x = 4, you would really be evaluating g(-4). Or, if you wanted to evaluate g(-x) when x = -9, you would really be evaluating g(9).
This is just what g(-x) looks like — evaluating the function g at the opposite input.
See the next exercise to explore the transformation y = g(-x) graphically.

li.p: The function g(x) is a reflection of f(x) over the x-axis, making all of the outputs of those functions opposites of each other.
Therefore, g(x) \amp= -f(x) \amp= -(x+)^4
Similarly, the function h(x) is a reflection of f(x) over the y-axis, making the output values the same at oppostite inputs.
Therefore, h(x) \amp= f(-x) \amp= (-x+)^4
